Review MXene quantum dots of Ti3C2: Properties, synthesis, and energy-related applications Chen Guan a b Xiaoyang Yue a b Jiajie Fan c Quanjun Xiang a b * a Yangtze Delta Region Institute (Huzhou), University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Huzhou 313001, Zhejiang, China Yangtze Delta Region Institute (Huzhou) University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Huzhou Zhejiang 313001 China Yangtze Delta Region Institute (Huzhou), University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Huzhou 313001, Zhejiang, China b State Key Laboratory of Electronic Thin Film and Integrated Devices, School of Electronic Science and Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 610054, Sichuan, China State Key Laboratory of Electronic Thin Film and Integrated Devices School of Electronic Science and Engineering University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Chengdu Sichuan 610054 China State Key Laboratory of Electronic Thin Film and Integrated Devices, School of Electronic Science and Engineering, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 610054, Sichuan, China c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou Henan 450002 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China * Corresponding author The emerging two-dimensional MXene-derived quantum dots (MQDs) have garnered considerable research interest owing to their abundant active edge atoms, excellent electrical conductivity, and remarkable optical properties. Compared with their two-dimensional (2D) counterpart MXene, MQDs with forceful size and quantum confinement effects exhibit more unparalleled properties and have considerably contributed to the advanced photocatalysis, detection, energy storage, and biomedicine fields. This critical review summarizes the fundamental properties of MQDs in terms of structure, electricity, and optics. The mechanism, characteristics, and comparisons of two typical synthesis strategies (traditional chemical method and novel fluorine-free or chemical-free method) are also presented. Furthermore, the similarities and differences between MQDs and 2D MXenes are introduced in terms of their functional groups, light absorption capacity, energy band structure, and other properties. Moreover, recent advances in the applications of MQD-based materials for energy conversion and storage (ECS) are discussed, including photocatalysis, batteries, and supercapacitors. Finally, current challenges and future opportunities for advancing MQD-based materials in the promising ECS field are presented. Graphical abstract This review presents the mechanism, characteristics, and comparisons of traditional chemical methods with novel fluorine-free/chemical-free methods and discusses the similarities and differences between MXene-derived quantum dots and 2D MXenes in terms of functional groups, light absorption capacity, energy band structure, and other properties. Keywords MXene quantum dots Energy conversion and storage Synthesis method Photocatalysis Fundamental property 1 Introduction With the rapid advancements in industrialization and urbanization in recent years, the increasingly severe global energy crisis has become an urgent problem for mankind, necessitating the development of advanced materials with a high energy conversion and storage efficiency. In previous reports, two-dimensional (2D) materials [1]—such as graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides [2], black phosphorene [3,4], hexagonal boron nitride [5], and silicene [6]—have shown potential applications in energy conversion and storage (ECS) systems. MXenes, as a new class of 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides, have attracted considerable attention since they were first synthesized in 2011 [7] and are expected to be the dominant materials for ECS. Typically, 2D MXenes are fabricated via the selective chemical etching of A layers of the MAX phase (where M represents an early transition metal element, A represents the element of groups IIIA and IVA, and X represents C and/or N). Over 70 MAX phases have been developed so far, and at least 30 types of MXenes have been experimentally synthesized [8]. MXenes show excellent electrical conductivity, abundant functional groups (–O, –OH, and –F groups), large planes for charge storage, and customizable surface chemistry. Compared with other 2D materials, MXenes exhibit superior characteristics, thus showing considerable potential in ECS applications such as photocatalysis (hydrogen production, CO2 reduction, and nitrogen fixation) [9–15], batteries [16], supercapacitors [17–19], and solar cells [20–27]. Compared with 2D MXenes, their counterparts in the form of quantum dots (QDs) (diameter usually <10 nm) show several significant properties owing to the forceful quantum confinement and size effects and simultaneously inherit the characteristics of the parent 2D forms [28]. Recently, the first example of MXene-derived QDs (MQDs), namely, Ti3C2, which shows a strong photoluminescence (PL) and high quantum yields, was reported. In particular, the lateral size of this MQD could be tuned to 2.9–6.2 nm [29]. The advent of nanoscale MQDs has sparked an insatiable passion for theoretical and experimental studies on MQDs. Ti3C2 QDs have been experimentally proven to show significant light absorptivity owing to the strong quantum confinement effect. Compared with 2D MXenes, a considerably improved CO2 photoreduction performance can be achieved by decorating materials with MQDs (e.g., Ti3C2 QDs) to realize a heterogeneous structure. The introduction of MQDs can expand the light absorption range of the material, improve light absorption efficiency, and achieve efficient electron transmission by reducing the bending of the energy band and the recombination of photogenerated carriers. Moreover, when used as electrode materials for Li-S batteries, MQDs showing excellent metallic conductivity can substantially reduce the interfacial resistance and increase the redox ability of sulfur species, yielding enhanced battery performance. Furthermore, owing to their natural hydrophilicity and satisfactory biocompatibility, the applicability of MQDs can be expanded to metal ion detection, biological imaging, and optoelectronics. Research on MQDs is flourishing, however, relevant reviews on advancements in MQDs are limited. This review summarizes the fundamental properties of MQDs in terms of structure, electricity, and optics. In addition, various MQD synthesis methods—such as the hydrothermal/solvothermal method, molten salt synthesis, acoustomicrofluidic method, and two-step ultrasound method—are enumerated. Subsequently, a detailed analysis and comparison of MXenes and MQDs are presented, mainly in terms of their functional groups, light absorption, and energy band structure. Furthermore, recent advances in ECS applications using MQD-based materials are discussed, including photocatalysis [30–35], batteries [16], and supercapacitors [17,19], and the crucial role played by MQDs in these applications is emphasized. Finally, future opportunities and challenges associated with MQDs in the ECS field are discussed (Fig. 1 ). This review is expected to guide new MQD-related research directions and considerably contribute to the ECS field. 2 Properties of MQDs When the lateral size of MXenes is < 10 nm, the semiconductors are generally referred to as nanostructure MXene QDs (Fig. 2 ). MXenes with 2D structures show several fascinating properties. Thus, MQDs inherit the intrinsic properties of their 2D counterparts as well as exhibit unique characteristics owing to their forceful size and quantum confinement effects [9]. 2.1 Structural properties MQDs present hexagonal symmetry, similar to the MAX phases [36,37], and are formed by separating bulk layered 2D MXenes. The structural formula of MQDs is usually M n+1X n or M n+1X n T x [2], where M represents an early transition metal element, X represents C and/or N, T represents various terminal surface groups, such as –F, –O, and –OH, and n = 1–3. Previous studies have shown that –OH groups can be converted into −O groups by metal adsorption or under high temperature conditions, and the number of OH functional groups and O decreases and increases, respectively, as the temperature increases. Furthermore, MQDs terminated with –O and –OH functional groups show enhanced stability because the –F group is easily replaced by the –OH group in water. 2.2 Electronic properties In principle, MQDs show a high electron density close to the Fermi level (E F) owing to the d-layer electrons from M atoms, thus exhibiting metallic conductivity [38]. Such an electronic structure could be verified using density functional theory (DFT) calculations; the density of states (DOS) of Ti3C2 QDs shows multiple electronic states that cross the E F, indicating that Ti3C2 QDs present excellent electrical conductivity and can favor electron transport. However, the conductivity of MQDs can change very easily; adjusting the terminal functional groups and components of MQDs can drastically alter the conductivity. Fully functionalized MXenes are mechanically and thermodynamically stable systems, and nanoscale MQDs can exhibit similar properties. All MQDs are metallic materials without any surface functionalization. However, after functionalization, some materials—such as ScCF2, Sc2C(OH)2, and Sc2CO2—become semiconductors with energy gaps of ~0.25–2.0 eV [39,40]. Moreover, doping with other elements drastically enhances the electronic properties of MQDs. Based on the charge-transfer mechanism (Fig. 3 ), nitrogen doping-introduced trap states close to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital are obtained, promoting electron transfer, increasing the carrier lifetime, and improving the PL quantum yield (PLQY). P-doped and N-P-codoped Ti3C2 QDs have been investigated, with the distribution of the electron density difference reflecting their electron transfer behavior between bonding atoms. The red and blue isosurfaces in Fig. 4 show electron accumulation and depletion during the chemical bond formation process, respectively. In Fig. 4, the enhanced blue color indicates electron depletion, demonstrating that impurity atoms induce charge transfer and increase the PLQYs of the N-P-functionalized MQDs. The improved electronic and optical properties of MQDs will broaden their applications in the biomedicine and photocatalysis fields. 2.3 Optical properties MQDs show remarkable light absorption characteristics in the ultraviolet (UV) to near-infrared (NIR) range because their energy band structure can be controlled and modulated by adjusting their terminal functional group and composition. They exhibit strong light absorption in the UV region, with a maximum absorption peak at ~213 nm and excitation-dependent fluorescence emission maximum at 360 nm. MQDs are excellent electrochemical sensors because of their strong UV light absorption and fluorescence characteristics; they can detect H2O2 concentrations down to 5 nm when used as electrode materials, which is the lowest value yet achieved using Ti3C2T z MQD electrochemical sensors. The degree of oxidation of MQDs significantly affects their PL performance. MQDs synthesized using the acoustomicrofluidic method show a stronger PL intensity than those synthesized using the hydrothermal method, which has a high TiO2−x F x content. Moreover, MQDs achieve strong absorption in the infrared region, and the NIR and band absorbances are enhanced considerably as the MQD concentration increases. MQDs are promising materials for photothermal therapy because of their infrared absorption characteristics as well as their good biocompatibility and high photothermal conversion efficiency [41–48]. 3 Synthesis of MQDs QD synthesis methods have been developed extensively over the past few years. Two typical strategies are available: (1) the top-down method, which involves cracking large precursors and continuously reducing the material size, and (2) bottom-up method, which employs in situ growth to grow molecular materials into QDs. The aforementioned methods are also suitable for synthesizing MQDs because they are significant parts of QDs. Two general preparation approaches have been proposed: traditional chemical methods and novel fluorine-free or chemical-free methods. The size and morphology of MQDs as well as their band structure and internal defects can be varied using different synthesis methods and conditions to ensure their enhanced usage in practical production and lives. This section catalogs the typical MQD synthesis strategies, clarifies the synthesis mechanism in detail using specific examples, and highlights advantages and limitations of different methods (Table 1 ). Moreover, feasible and targeted improvement measures are provided. 3.1 Traditional chemical methods In traditional chemical methods, 2D MXenes are first obtained by separating the bulk layered precursors using chemical methods; then, the obtained MXene sheets are cut to form MQDs [17–19,50]. Oxygen-containing functional groups are formed on the surface of 2D MXenes in most traditional chemical methods, which may generate defects [51]. The defects can act as chemical reaction sites, allowing the 2D MXene to be cut into QDs [52,53]. Traditional chemical methods benefit from abundant raw resources and offer concise operation as well as large-scale production. However, they are limited owing to drawbacks such as a low output, hazardous chemical usage, and high temperatures [54,55]. Traditional chemical methods mainly include hydrothermal, solvothermal, molten salt, ultrasonic, ball milling, acid reflux, intercalation, and combined methods (Fig. 5 ). The hydrothermal method is the most common among the aforementioned synthesis methods. In this method, a chemical reaction occurs under conditions of high temperatures and pressures in a closed pressure vessel using water as the solvent. In particular, the hydrothermal method uses 2D MXenes as precursors; the size, morphology, and properties of MQDs can be adjusted by changing the solution pH (pH = 6–9), reaction temperature (100–150 °C), and reaction time (based on the hydrothermal temperature and solution pH, a high temperature and pH afford a short reaction time). For the hydrothermal synthesis of Ti3C2 QDs, the A layer in the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase is first etched using a certain concentration of hydrofluoric acid (HF). Then, Ti3C2 QDs can be obtained by hydrothermally cutting layered Ti3C2 MXenes. Exploiting the merits of the hydrothermal method, the preparation of Ti3C2 MQDs using the facile hydrothermal method could produce several types of colloidal MQDs under different reaction temperatures. Interestingly, the lateral particle size of MQDs was linearly related to the reaction temperature, with average sizes of 2.9, 3.7, and 6.2 nm obtained at 100, 120, and 150 °C, respectively. Moreover, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) results have shown that the Ti3C2 MQDs exhibit the original structure of MXenes at a low reaction temperature (100 °C). The structure of MQDs changes as the temperature increases until it reaches 150 °C, at which point several Ti atoms are released and the MQD structure becomes amorphous. MXenes are prone to oxidation, and the use of hydrothermal methods for MQD synthesis will aggravate this process. The structural integrity of the oxidized MQDs is compromised, producing a high TiO2 content (40%–80%), which will affect their performance in practical applications, such as a considerably deteriorated catalytic activity in the cancer therapy field. Therefore, a more precise control of hydrothermal parameters and novel synthetic methods should still be investigated to prevent MQD oxidation. Compared with the hydrothermal method, the solvothermal method mainly uses inorganic solvents—such as ethanol, dimethylformamide (DMF), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [56]—instead of water as the reaction medium, which can enable better control of the morphology, diameter (DMSO < ethanol < DMF), and dispersion of MQDs [57,58]. Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets are generally employed as precursors to synthesize Ti3C2T x QDs using the solvothermal method with different organic solvents, such as ethanol, DMSO, and DMF, affording three well-dispersed stable samples with different colors. The average sizes and quantum yields of the MQD samples obtained using the DMF, ethanol, and DMSO solvents were 3.3 ± 0.2 nm and 10.7%, 2.5 ± 0.2 nm and 6.9%, and 1.8 ± 0.1 nm and 4.1%, respectively. Further, the difference in the average size and quantum yield is mainly attributed to the combined effect of the solvent's polarity, boiling point, and degree of oxidation. However, the proportion of each factor in the synergistic effect cannot be accurately defined, and other organic solvents should be studied to better control the size and quantum yields of MQDs. The single hydrothermal/solvothermal method has been extensively investigated; however, combining it with the ultrasound method could offer an improved strategy [59–61]. Ultrasonic treatment forms acoustic cavitation and shockwaves in the solvent. Moreover, ultrasound is conducive to the degassing of 2D MXene precursors, as well as accelerating their delamination and fragmentation processes, thereby effectively suppressing the oxidation of MXenes [62,63]. Relevant studies have confirmed that combining the hydrothermal method with ultrasound effectively reduces the dimensions of MQDs and improves their optical properties. In particular, the as-prepared 2D MXenes were subjected to two sonication treatments: tip sonication (120 W for 6 h) and bath sonication (300 W for 10 h). Then, the dispersion was hydrothermally treated at 120 °C in a N2 atmosphere overnight. The size of the as-prepared Ti3C2 QDs was mainly in the range of 2–5 nm, and the QDs showed enhanced light absorption characteristics and a long fluorescence electron lifetime. This synthesis method is complex, and the steps should be simplified for practical production applications. In all the aforementioned methods, 2D MXenes are used as precursors; however, molten salt synthesis uses molecular materials as precursors [64], offering the advantages of easy functionalization, high atom usage, and a more precise morphology control [65,66]. Cheng et al. [65] successfully synthesized Mo2C QDs and loaded them on carbon nanosheets via a simple molten salt synthesis using molybdenum acetylacetonate, sucrose, and sodium chloride as raw materials (calcinated at 800 °C for 2 h under Ar protection). HRTEM image showed that the size of the Mo2C QDs ranged from 2 to 3 nm (Fig. 6(c) ). Furthermore, scanning transmission electron microscopic (STEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopic (EDS) results confirmed that the as-prepared ultrasmall QDs were Mo2C QDs, which were evenly distributed on the carbon nanosheets. Mo2C QDs synthesized using this method exhibit high catalytic activity and nitrogen adsorption energy (Fig. 6(f)). The bottom-up strategy for synthesizing MQDs using molecular materials as precursors is currently irreplaceable because of its low-toxicity raw material usage, simple preparation, easy mass production, good crystallinity, monodispersity, and many other properties. This research topic has potential for improvement and requires further studies. 3.2 Novel fluorine-free/chemical-free methods In nearly all the aforementioned methods for synthesizing MQDs, time-consuming processes, redundant procedures, and hazardous chemicals are unavoidable. Notably, MQDs synthesized via traditional chemical methods frequently undergo severe oxidation. For example, the Ti3C2T z sample, with the maximum TiO2 content of 40%–80%, is synthesized using such a method. Furthermore, HF is commonly used to etch the bulk MAX phase to form MXenes; however, HF is a renowned highly corrosive reagent, which considerable increases the risk and complexity of the synthesis. Therefore, it is critical to develop novel fluorine-free or chemical-free methods to simplify MQD synthesis. Novel fluorine-free or chemical-free methods, mainly including the acoustomicrofluidic and direct ultrasound methods, offer safety, preserve the material's integrity, and reduce oxidation. The acoustomicrofluidic method is a chemical-free approach that uses hybrid sound waves generated by high-frequency (MHz-order) nanometer-order electromechanical vibrations to effectively nebulize the suspension of multilayer MXenes into predominantly monolayer nanosheets and QDs by reducing the dimensions (Fig. 7 ). Notably, this hybrid sound wave is called a surface-reflected bulk wave (SRBW), which shows a 10 million g's surface acceleration and a strong evanescent electric field of 107 V/m. Alijani et al. [67] successfully fabricated Ti3C2T z QDs using the acoustomicrofluidic method. Regulating the number of nebulization cycles can considerably change the thickness and average size of Ti3C2T z QDs. The thickness of the MQDs gradually decreases to 8.5 ± 2.6, 4.8 ± 1.0, and 1.1 ± 0.4 nm in the cases of 1, 5, and 10 nebulization cycles, respectively. However, a continuous increase in the number of nebulization cycles could not reduce the thickness of Ti3C2T z QDs, while their lateral dimensions reduced only slightly. After 20 nebulization cycles, the mean thickness and size were 1.1 ± 0.2 and 7.8 ± 5.2 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic results may be preserved with a high degree of integrity in relation to the original precursor using this approach. The TiO2−x F x content in the MQDs (9%, 13%, and 14% for 1, 5, and 10 nebulization cycles, respectively) remained almost unchanged relative to that of the original precursor (14%), proving that the material was preserved from any appreciable oxidation. Direct ultrasound is another fluorine-free method for preparing MQDs, offering a safe and simple operation. The direct ultrasound method is generally divided into two steps: in the first step, the probe ultrasound reduces the size of the bulk precursor and exposes more fresh edges and surfaces to the etching solution; the second step involves a water-bath ultrasound to split the sheet-like MXene into small pieces, referred to as MQDs [68]. In detail, a mixture of Ti3AlC2 powders, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) (28.6%), and water was first subjected to tip sonication (480 W for 6 h). Then, the dispersions were treated with bath sonication (300 W for 10 h). Based on the transmission electron microscopic and AFM results, the average lateral size and thickness were 4.9 ± 0.6 nm and 1.2 ± 0.3 nm, respectively. Moreover, the as-prepared Ti3C2 QDs showed enhanced broadband and NIR absorbances. Although this fluorine-free method is simple and safe to use and can produce satisfactory MQDs when the preparation conditions are carefully controlled, other assisted etching solvents should be further explored to better control the performance of MQDs. 4 Comparison of MQDs and 2D MXenes Multiple layers of MXene nanosheets are stacked to afford 2D MXenes, and MQDs are further stripped of 2D counterparts to reduce their dimensions. MQDs comprise generally few or even single layers, and their lateral size is commonly < 10 nm. Because they are all derived from the original MAX phase, MXene and MQDs have almost the same functional group compositions, such as –O, –F, and –OH [69,70]. MQDs show a higher optical absorption ability than 2D MXenes. Owing to their ultrasmall size, MQDs can enhance their optical harvesting capability by decreasing the transmittance and refractive index, usually occurring in the case of large particles. The ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum shows that Cu2O NW/Cu decorated with Ti3C2 QDs can simultaneously show improved light absorption efficiency and light absorption range, whereas the Cu2O NW/Cu decorated with nanosheets only shows enhanced light absorption efficiency (Fig. 8 ). The bandgap of Ti3C2 QD-decorated Cu2O NW/Cu is 2.02 eV, smaller than that of Ti3C2 sheet-decorated Cu2O NW/Cu (2.14 eV), indicating that Ti3C2 QDs show a better light absorption gain effect on Cu2O NW/Cu than MXene sheets [13]. The unparalleled optical absorption ability of MQDs has enabled remarkable performance for photocatalytic systems and has considerably contributed to the photocatalysis field. The E F of MQDs can be more negative than that of 2D MXenes, enabling electron accumulation on the MQDs, further promoting the reduction of CO2 and hydrogen. The E F of O-terminated Ti3C2 QDs and Ti3C2 sheets has been estimated using DFT calculations [13]. The E F (vs. NHE, pH = 7) of Ti3C2 QDs was calculated to be −0.523 V, whereas that of Ti3C2 sheets was 0.71 V (vs. NHE, pH = 7). When electrons are excited from the valence band to the conduction band (CB), they tend to accumulate in Ti3C2 QDs because the conductivity of Ti3C2 QDs is high and the E F is less negative than that in the case of the CB. The accumulated electrons could stimulate this reduction reaction because the E F of Ti3C2 QDs is more negative than the redox potential of CO2 to methanol and H+ to H2. Alternatively, the E F of Ti3C2 sheets is relatively positive, which is unideal for catalytic reactions (Fig. 9 ). In addition, MQDs show a larger pore size and specific surface area as well as higher sensitivity and relatively better stability characteristics than 2D MXenes. The result of the zeta potential diagram shows that the value of MQDs is relatively higher under the same pH conditions than the value of 2D MXenes, implying that MQDs show better stability. MQDs with increased stability are less susceptible to changes under harsh reaction conditions, ensuring their superior performance in various applications [71,72]. In summary, MXenes and MQDs exhibit several identical properties because they are both products of the MAX phase exfoliation (Table 2 ). However, because of differences in the dimensions, the properties of the composites may differ in terms of the number of reaction sites and electronic limitations of nanostructures, possibly affecting their performance in practical applications. In terms of photocatalytic H2 generation, both MQD- and MXene-based composites show a drastically increased H2 yield as well as effectively promoted light absorption and usage. They can also form a Schottky junction at the heterojunction interface to facilitate the separation of photogenerated carriers. For example, Fig. 10 shows that BiVO4@ZnIn2S4 decorated with MQDs (Ti3C2) shows a lower work function and higher E F than other three samples, indicating an enhanced built-in electric field and improved carrier separation efficiency [73]. Similarly, 2D MXenes (Ti3C2T x ) and ZnIn2S4 could form a Schottky junction to boost the separation of photoexcited electron-hole pairs at the heterojunction interface (Fig. 11 ). However, 2D MXenes and MQDs differ in terms of their key roles in composites. For example, 2D MXenes primarily act as support structures for composites to inhibit aggregation and reduce the particle size. Alternatively, MQDs are mainly used as cocatalysts because their small size allows them to provide more active sites and improve the redox reaction of the main catalyst [75]. 5 Applications of MQDs MQDs have been extensively studied and applied in various fields, particularly in the ECS filed, owing to their intrinsic characteristics inherited from 2D MXenes and unique quantum confinement effect. This section outlines the recent progress in MQDs in the ECS field in terms of photocatalysis, batteries, supercapacitors, and other applications [76]. Some representative cases are summarized in Table 3 . 5.1 Photocatalysis The progress of human civilization is increasingly threatened by energy and environmental challenges. The development of new and environmentally friendly approaches is urgently needed to solve the problems of environmental pollution and energy shortage; the intelligent use of solar energy is a sustainable method to address this increasingly severe problem. Using sunlight-driven photocatalytic technology, which is inspired by plant photosynthesis, green and environmentally friendly energy conversion can be achieved. Several photocatalysts—such as g-C3N4, TiO2, and CdS—have been studied since Fujishima and Honda first discovered the photoelectric catalytic splitting of water to produce H2 on TiO2 electrodes in 1972 [77–86]. MQDs have recently been regarded as promising photocatalysts/cocatalysts because of their excellent light absorption characteristics, abundant active sites, and remarkable metallic conductivity. Based on these fundamental characteristics, MQDs have been extensively explored in the hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, nitrogen fixation, and other processes. Semiconductor photocatalytic hydrogen production is attracting increasing attention because of the growing energy consumption and consequent environmental pollution problems. The efficiency of a single semiconductor photocatalyst is insufficient, and when combined with MQDs, the excellent metallic conductivity of MQDs will accelerate the carrier transfer efficiency and effectively avoid the rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers. This considerably improves the efficiency of hydrogen production. A tight heterostructure was afforded by loading Ti3C2 QDs onto g-C3N4 nanosheets (Fig. 12 ). Consequently, the photocatalytic H2 production rate was considerably higher than that of pure g-C3N4 nanosheets, Pt/g-C3N4, and Ti3C2 nanosheet/g-C3N4 [14]. The optimized g-C3N4@Ti3C2 QD composite exhibited high-efficiency photocatalytic performance mainly because the Ti3C2 QD as a cocatalyst showed a small particle size, which can improve the specific surface area and provide more reactive sites. Fig. 12 shows that Ti3C2 QDs are evenly anchored on g-C3N4 NSs. Ti3C2 QDs could promote the rapid migration of photogenerated electrons because of the intimate connection at their interface and excellent conductivity. Therefore, electrons can quickly participate in the hydrogen production reaction to improve the photocatalytic performance. The use of MQDs as cocatalysts broadens the selection range of photocatalytic hydrogen production cocatalysts, not limited to Pt, and provides constructive ideas for researching more efficient cocatalysts [87–91]. Immoderate consumption of fossil energy results in the excessive emission and accumulation of carbon dioxide. As a greenhouse gas, CO2 is the main cause of global warming. The photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to generate renewable hydrocarbon fuels can effectively address both the greenhouse effect and energy shortage problems [92–96]. Various photocatalysts have been widely used to improve the conversion efficiency of CO2 after Inoue et al. [97] reported the photoelectric catalytic reduction of CO2 to methanol in 1979 [98–103]. However, the lack of surface adsorption and active sites in most single-component photocatalysts considerably limits their practical application. Researchers have recently discovered that MQDs show a wider light response range, relatively more negative E F, and more active edge sites, which could provide new insights into single-component catalyst defects [104,105]. Therefore, MQD-based photocatalysts are widely used in CO2 reduction. For example, Ti3C2 QDs, Cu2O NWs, and Cu could form a unique heterostructure using a simple electrostatic self-assembly method, which has been used for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into methanol. The methanol yield produced by the Ti3C2 QD/Cu2O NW/Cu was 2.15 times that of the Ti3C2 sheet/Cu2O NW/Cu. The drastically improved performance is attributed to the Ti3C2 QDs, which broadened the light absorption range, improved light absorption efficiency, and enhanced the transmission of electrons by reducing the band bending and the recombination of photogenerated carriers. In addition, a more negative E F of Ti3C2 QDs makes them more conducive to CO2 reduction. Unfortunately, this work only uses the Ti3C2 concentration for loading, and more research is needed to optimize the loading for increased carbon dioxide reduction efficiency. Ammonia is an indispensable chemical used in industries and agriculture. Conventionally, almost 90% of ammonia is produced via the Haber-Bosch process under strict reaction conditions (high temperatures and pressures). The search for a green energy technology to convert nitrogen (N2) into ammonia (NH3) has attracted considerable attention globally. Recently, photocatalytic nitrogen fixation has been deemed a promising technology because it offers clean and sustainable advantages [106–109]. Moreover, newly emerging MQD-based photocatalysts have been investigated for photocatalytic nitrogen. A novel Ni MOF decorated with Ti3C2 QDs has been synthesized using a simple electrostatic self-assembly method [15], and the two components formed a special type II heterogeneous structure (Fig. 13 ). The ammonia yield of the Ti3C2 QD/Ni MOF composite was 4 times higher than that of the pure Ni MOF composite. Because Ti3C2 QDs show a graphene-like structure, they can enhance carrier mobility, which greatly compensates for the weakness of MOF materials. The fundamental requisite step in the N2 photoreduction reaction is the physical adsorption of N2 molecules, and an enhanced adsorption capacity can increase the NH3 yield. MQDs exhibit a larger specific surface area and more surface adsorption sites because of the strong size effect, considerably improving the physical adsorption capacity of the Ni MOF for N2 molecules. Furthermore, Ti3C2 QDs could show a broadened energy band and enhanced light absorptivity, thereby substantially enhancing the photocatalytic performance. Although the use of MQD-based materials for the photocatalytic reduction of N2 is intriguing, research on this subject is still limited. More intuitive tests—such as Kelvin probe force microscopy—are required to prove the specific electron migration path and built-in electric field formed between MQDs and semiconductor materials [110,111]. 5.2 Batteries The continuous development of energy storage materials has been inspired by the rapid increase in the demand for new energy electric vehicles, various electronic devices, and large-scale smart grids. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as advanced energy storage materials because of the significant advantages of their cathode material (sulfur), such as a high theoretical specific capacity, abundant natural reserves, low costs, and environmental friendliness [112–114]. However, the use of the traditional conductive carbon material as a sulfur composite cathode has obvious limitations. The weak interaction between low-polarity carbon and high-polarity lithium polysulfide (LiPS), poor adsorption capacity of carbon-based materials, dissolution of LiPS, and shuttle effect all contribute to a considerable decrease in the battery capacity after long-term use. Other polar materials—such as sulfides, carbides, and transition metal oxides—have been used as additives for the carbon body; however, they all have some drawbacks such as the formation of heterogeneous crystal grain boundaries and interfaces, which increases resistance, enables the easy collapse of the structure, and reduces the battery capacity. Owing to these limitations, Li-S batteries are commercially unavailable on a large scale [115–120]. MXenes are emerging two-dimensional layered materials with an outstanding theoretical lithium storage capacity, excellent electronic conductivity and mechanical properties, low Li migration barrier, and low operating voltage range. In particular, the abundant terminal polar groups (such as –F, –O, and –OH) on the surface provide strong chemical interactions for capturing LiPS capture. Further, MQDs show a small size, exposing more surface terminals and effectively capturing LiPS. However, ultrasmall MQDs are prone to self-aggregation during carrier transfer, considerably hindering the efficient electron transmission [121,122]. Therefore, a unique structure of MXene nanosheets decorated with MQDs was constructed (Fig. 14 ) [16]. This novel structure can tightly combine the two components, thus substantially promoting the transfer efficiency of interface electrons. Notably, high-density MQDs can provide several polar sites, considerably preventing the dissolution and shuttle effect of LiPS; moreover, they can mediate the sulfur penetration and deposition of solid discharge products, thus increasing sulfur usage and improving Li-S battery performance. A Ti3C2T x QD-Ti3C2T x sheet electrode was experimentally proven to exhibit a high discharge capacity when the medium sulfur loading was 1.8 mg cm−2. In addition, a ultrahigh volume capacity and high areal capacity were simultaneously achieved under a high sulfur loading of 13.8 mg cm−2. Traditional carbon-based cathode materials show a more inferior electrochemical performance. The sulfur evolution mechanism during discharge shows that uniformly distributing high-density ultrafine MQDs on the surface of MXene nanosheets considerably reduces the interface resistance and improves the redox kinetics of sulfur species, even at high current densities; furthermore, high sulfur loading can achieve high sulfur usage efficiency, resulting in significantly improved battery performance (Fig. 15 ). This innovative method gives us new ideas for improving the use of sulfur species as well as the performance of Li-S batteries. 5.3 Supercapacitors Supercapacitors are important energy storage devices. They are expected to be used in smart wearable devices, new energy vehicles, and other applications owing to their high energy density, fast charging and discharging capabilities, and long cycle life [123–125]. Gogotsi et al. [126] first demonstrated the use of 2D Ti3C2T x as a flexible electrode material in pseudocapacitance. So far, 2D MXenes have been studied extensively in the preparation and performance of supercapacitors because of their regular structure, excellent metallic conductivity, and good flexibility. Although research on MQDs for supercapacitors is still limited, MQDs show a considerable potential in supercapacitor applications because of their obvious quantum confinement effect and abundant functional groups [13]. Recently, the use of Ti3C2T x QDs as interlayer spacers of a positive electrode was found to significantly improve the performance of the fiber supercapacitor (Ti3C2T x nanosheet/Ti3C2T x QD/RGO fiber: M6M3RG1). Compared with other interlayer spacers, MQDs showed a well-defined structure and the same inherent characteristics as Ti3C2T x nanosheets, resulting in the minimal interaction between the two components. Moreover, the ion transmission efficiency of this specific composite material was improved using a novel network structure. The as-prepared fiber supercapacitor was experimentally proven to show rapid charge-discharge performance and an optimal capacitance behavior, achieving a maximum volumetric capacitance of 542 F cm−3 with 56% capacity retention (Fig. 16 ). Thus, using MQDs as supercapacitor electrode materials can produce significant performance improvements. 5.4 Other applications Biological imaging is a vital technology in the modern biomedicine field. It mainly involves the use of optical detection methods combined with molecular detection techniques to image cells or tissues and even organisms, which can quickly and conveniently provide researchers with clear and intuitive biological information [127–129]. Semiconductor QDs have been used as detection molecules for biological imaging; however, they usually contain heavy metals and their toxicity limits their practical applications [130]. Alternatively, nontoxic or low-toxicity MQDs show better biocompatibility in this field and are likely to become the new generation of excellent bioimaging materials [131]. So far, many researchers have confirmed the outstanding biological imaging capabilities of MQDs owing to their unparalleled fluorescence characteristics and ultrasmall size [132]. Recently, Ti3C2 MQDs were first reported for multicolor cell imaging [29]. The confocal images showed bright blue, green, and red colors under different excitation wavelengths. Furthermore, MQDs are mainly distributed in the cell membrane and cytoplasm, with some present in the nucleus, proving that MQDs can easily spread inside the cell without entering the nucleus (Fig. 17(d) ). Thus, MQDs can be used for efficient and safe biological imaging without damaging the nucleus, thus exhibiting considerable application prospects in the biomedicine field. Notably, this report only studies the application of Ti3C2 in the bioimaging field; other types of MQDs, such as V2C and Mo2C, should still be studied. The most suitable MQDs for bioimaging can be determined via comparisons [133,134]. 6 Conclusions and outlook In summary, a panoramic and systematic review of MQDs based on their unparalleled properties in terms of structure, electricity, and optics is presented. The MQD preparation methods are cataloged into traditional chemical methods and novel fluorine-free or chemical-free methods, with representative synthesis methods—such as the hydrothermal/solvothermal method, solvothermal combined with the ultrasonic method, and molten salt method—discussed for detailed analysis based on whether fluorine is involved. The advantages and disadvantages of various methods are also presented. Subsequently, the inherent characteristics of MQDs and MXene are compared, and a detailed investigation of their differences is performed in terms of functional groups, light absorption capacity, and energy band structure. Moreover, the review highlights the different applications of MQD-based materials in the ECS field, such as photocatalytic hydrogen production, CO2 reduction to hydrocarbon fuels, nitrogen fixation, batteries, and supercapacitors. Despite the achievement of significant progress and results to date, numerous theoretical and technical challenges and gaps still exists. 6.1 Improving the synthesis strategy of MQDs The strategy for synthesizing MQDs is mainly based on chemical methods. Generally, 2D MXenes are obtained by etching the MAX phase with a high-concentration corrosive acidic solution (such as HF), which is exceedingly dangerous and harmful to the human health. Recently, with the advancement of science and technology, some fluorine-free or chemical-free methods have been developed, such as the acoustomicrofluidic method and two-step direct ultrasonic method. These methods are clearly superior: they avoid the use of toxic substances and reduce the degree of oxidation of the synthesized samples. Nevertheless, related research is insufficient. Greater attention should be paid to improving these methods and exploring more advanced synthesis strategies to achieve high-performance MQDs. 6.2 Further exploration of the fundamental properties of MQDs MQDs show various unparalleled properties owing to their forceful size and quantum confinement effects. Several studies have experimentally confirmed that MQDs exhibit excellent photothermal conversion, fluorescence, photon, and photoelectric properties. However, most of the properties predicted using DFT calculations remain at the theoretical stage; for example, the magnetic properties of MXenes have rarely been experimentally proven, and only a few types of MXenes are predicted to exhibit magnetic properties using DFT calculations. Moreover, DOS and E F calculations show that O-terminated Ti3C2 presents abundant electronic states throughout the E F, indicating its significant electrical conductivity, which is yet to be experimentally confirmed. Moreover, many new features of MQDs have not been studied in detail, such as their transparent optical and chemiluminescence properties. In the future, we must focus on verifying the theoretically predicted properties and exploring new properties, which will expand our knowledge and understanding of MQDs and allow us to apply these properties to new research fields. 6.3 Enrich the modification methods of MQDs MQDs are widely used in photocatalysis, batteries, supercapacitors, and biomedicine fields owing to their excellent performance. However, the as-prepared original MQDs cannot be directly used in practice; several functional modification methods are often needed to achieve performance based on their intended functions. Recently, the commonly used functional modification methods include surface modification, composite construction, and heteroatom doping. Only some documents have been used in the research, which are very limited. Therefore, exploring more functional modification methods is crucial. For example, in the catalysis field, the strategy of anchoring MQDs could be used to immobilize MQDs on ideal carriers, thus reducing their accumulation behavior in practical applications and considerably improving their stability. In the biology and medicine fields, the core-shell structure could be adopted and biocompatibility materials—such as peptides, sugars, and proteins—could be used as coatings to modify MQDs, which can substantially reduce the matrix rejection while maintaining functionality. More advanced and diverse functional modification methods should be developed to construct multifunctional and efficient MQD-based materials, allowing their widespread usage in various fields. Further investigations should be conducted to focus on the aforementioned issues because they are crucial for the future development of MQDs. Overall, MQD-based materials are still a blue ocean, and our aim should be to increase efficiency, diversification, and stability. This review provides researchers with a panoramic and systematic understanding of MQDs and contributes to their future development. coredata.dc:description: The emerging two-dimensional MXene-derived quantum dots (MQDs) have garnered considerable research interest owing to their abundant active edge atoms, excellent electrical conductivity, and remarkable optical properties. Compared with their two-dimensional (2D) counterpart MXene, MQDs with forceful size and quantum confinement effects exhibit more unparalleled properties and have considerably contributed to the advanced photocatalysis, detection, energy storage, and biomedicine fields. This critical review summarizes the fundamental properties of MQDs in terms of structure, electricity, and optics. The mechanism, characteristics, and comparisons of two typical synthesis strategies (traditional chemical method and novel fluorine-free or chemical-free method) are also presented. Furthermore, the similarities and differences between MQDs and 2D MXenes are introduced in terms of their functional groups, light absorption capacity, energy band structure, and other properties. Moreover, recent advances in the applications of MQD-based materials for energy conversion and storage (ECS) are discussed, including photocatalysis, batteries, and supercapacitors. Finally, current challenges and future opportunities for advancing MQD-based materials in the promising ECS field are presented.

coredata.dc:title: MXene quantum dots of Ti3C2: Properties, synthesis, and energy-related applications
